head.title: Rote Lessons Don't Help Poor Children Learn

hedline.hl1: Rote Lessons Don't Help Poor Children Learn

abstract.p: Alfie Kohn letter deplores rote learning required of minority children attending charter schools (Aug 16 article); says it may help them do well on standardized tests, but tests measure what matters least

block.p: Re ''Seeking to Clone Schools of Success for Poor'' (front page, Aug. 16): It is disturbing enough to read of charter schools in which minority children are subjected ''to militaristic discipline and rituals'' and rote instruction.

But it is far more disheartening to see this approach described uncritically as ''successful'' solely on the basis of standardized test scores. Standardized tests measure what matters least, and raising test scores often requires sacrificing the more meaningful kinds of learning.

Re ''Seeking to Clone Schools of Success for Poor'' (front page, Aug. 16): It is disturbing enough to read of charter schools in which minority children are subjected ''to militaristic discipline and rituals'' and rote instruction.

But it is far more disheartening to see this approach described uncritically as ''successful'' solely on the basis of standardized test scores. Standardized tests measure what matters least, and raising test scores often requires sacrificing the more meaningful kinds of learning.

The more that poor children must chant right answers and fill in worksheets on command, the further they fall behind affluent children, who are more likely to get lessons that help them understand ideas.
